advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #3 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>As harware arguments wasn't sufficient, NothStar tried to promote software compatability and services.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1991)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This japanese advert indicates that there were at least 3 different models sold...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a German advertisement for the BIT-60 and BIT-90 models. Atari VCS-2600 cartridges are scattered in front of the BIT-60 to show that the it is really compatible with the VCS-2600 ! But strangely enough, there is no picture displayed on the TV. Were these models really working ? ;-)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This ad uses actors, except for IMSAI's Finance Director Hersch Mandelman as the "Milk Man".</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE FRONT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Description of the complete Atmos system.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said : <br><br> ''The computer which carried away America"<br><br> ''With its portable computers, Compaq became world number two on the market of the 16 bits computers. With a turnover of 240 million dollars in one year and a half, this young company established in Houston obtained the growth rate record of the American economic history." </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cover of a French Commodore-PC brochure.<br><br> 'Hats off to Commodore!' </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT SEPT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> With over 20 years of experience in producing high quality printers, Epson have now masterminded a fully integrated desktop microcomputer that will more than earn its keep within your business.<br> The QX-IO is capable of performing all the tasks you will ever require of it, quickly and efficiently. Installation of the QX-IO can be carried out with the minimum of interruption, and with its easily understandable keyboard, it is simplicity itself to operate. Having such a diverse range of software packages available such as database from Pearl and office productivity and accountancy from Peachtree with CP/M and multifont BASIC as standard, the QX-IO can supply all the answers whatever your business.<br> Just look at what's on offer: a big memory - 192k upgradable to 256k RAM and all the graphics you'll ever need - and high resolution graphics at that.<br> The ability to communicate easily with other machines, including our own HX-20 and the advantage of using our fine range of printers, make the QX-lO a totally versatile system at a price you'll find impossible to equal.<br> £1735 plus VAT.<br> If you're looking at micros, look at the QX-IO. The system with all the answers. </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, APRIL 1987</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computer World magazine.<br> Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> It's an extraordinarily powerful machine which offers word-processing, spreadsheet, and a set of time and data-management tools in a single, highly porlable package.<br> At £199.95. the Z88 is supplied with 32K resident RAM. Extra 32K costs under £20, extra 128K under £50!<br> And heavy users Will be able to expand the RAM to an astonishing 3 Mbytes, using plug-in RAM cartridges.<br> For printing text or data, the Z88 connects direcly to most popular RS232 compatible printers, while for permanent storage the Z88 employs removable solid state EPROM cartridges - no tape to break, no delicate disc to damage.<br> Though the Z88 is a powerful, full facility, self-contained computer, it also acts as an extension of an office micro, connecting directly to allow exchange of text or data.<br> For every personal computer user, the Z88 offers a comprehensive specification in a package of unparalleled portability.</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>November 1987<br><br> Special Spectrum offers before christmas period. Packages including a Sinclair joystick and 6 games.<br><br> Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> The new Sinclair ZX Spectrum+3 is a real hero because it helps you to be one.<br> The fantastic 128K memory gives you the power to outsmart the most sophisticated ennemy...<br> ...But the real hero is the person who buy it...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.museo8bits.com" target="_blank">www.museo8bits.com</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #2 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JUL 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>“Why be content with a video game system?<br> Today, the VIC-20 is available at a special price.”<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This was probably the very first advert of the SC3000 as the pictured machine still was a Japanese version.<br> Notice that the price is in Australian$, probably without the Basic cartridge which is not mentioned in the advert. <br><br> The SC-3000 was very popular in New Zealand in the early to mid 80's. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH LEAFLET COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>One found the same leaflet in various countries, translated in many languages.<br><br> Title was: 'Sirius 1, the professional computer to the power of 16' </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIAGRAMS</strong></font><br><blockquote>PMI-80 diagram located in the case cover.<br> If you are interested in more diagrams of the PMI-80, dowload this zipped <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/Museum/downloads/Tesla_PMI80_Diagrams.zip">file</a> holding three diagrams of the whole system.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Under all pictures of the promotional guide, you can read : "all screenshots are real and have not been retouched". <br><br> Really?</blockquote>

computer.description:
The picture shows a computer called the WITCH which stood for Wolverhampton Instrument for Teaching Computing from Harwell. It was built at AERE Harwell in 1948 and was won by the then Wolverhampton and South Staffordshire Technical College in a national competition in 1957. The photograph above was taken in 1961.
The technology consisted of mixture of 1940's vintage telephone exchange technology (GPO 3000 type relays) and early nuclear instrumentation (Dekatron tubes).
A Dekatron tube was a device rather similar to a neon indicator light except that it had 10 anodes rather than one. By carefully timed and shaped steering pulses on intermediate electrodes the active glow could be moved from one anode to another. Dekatrons were used for event counting in early nuclear instrumentation before the advent of solid state electronics. In the WITCH the Dekatrons were used for storing digits of numbers. A row of 10 dekatrons could store a single number.
The WITCH was a very slow computer by modern standards. It took it
- 2 seconds to add or subtract 2 numbers - 5 seconds to multiply two numbers - 15 seconds to divide two numbers. (Division by zero took rather longer.) The fully developed configuration at Wolverhampton had 90 memory locations. Programs were read from a paper tape reader in an adjacent room.
There were actually 6 electromechanical paper tape readers, the current one being selectable under program control. Whenever the WITCH had finished executing an instruction it read the next instruction from the current paper tape reader. Program loops were constructed with the aid of a pot of glue.
One unfortunate problem with paper tape loops was the tendency of the mechanical readers to poke extra holes in the paper tape after several passes. If your job was sufficiently important you could use special linen tape which was more resistant to this effect.
It was possible to determine the contents of any memory location by simply examining the relevant row of Dekatrons. The storage locations were in the two racks visible on the left hand side of the picture. The central rack of electronics contained the arithmetic and control units. It was possible to watch the multiplication of two numbers by seeing the partial products building up in the accumulator (another row of Dekatrons).
The WITCH was used for many years for introductory and schools' courses. In its later years it became increasingly unreliable and spares become difficult to obtain. Eventually, in the mid 1970s, it was retired to the Birmingham's Museum Collections Centre, where it is still on display.
______________
Credits: Peter Burden & University of Wolverhampton
computer.name: WITCH

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> SECTION OF THE WITCH</strong></font><br><blockquote>A section of the relay computer designed at the Atomic Energy Authority's Harwell establishment in 1951. This machine gave faithful service for many years, being donated to Wolverhampton College of Technology in 1957. It was then re-named WITCH (Wolverhampton Instrument for Teaching Computation from Harwell) and continued to initiate the uninitiated into the mysteries of computing until its retirement in 1973. <p class="petitgris">Picture credit: United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority, Harwell, (R. C. M. Barnes)</p></blockquote>
